etymologies: late 15th century (in the sense ‘trail, marks left behind’): the noun from Old French trac, perhaps from Low German or Dutch trek ‘draft, drawing’; the verb (current senses dating from the mid 16th century) from French traquer or directly from the noun

definitions: a rough path or minor road, typically one beaten by use rather than constructed

examples.text: follow the track to the farm

shortDefinitions: rough path or road

definitions: a prepared course or circuit for athletes, horses, motor vehicles, bicycles, or dogs to race on

examples.text: a Formula One Grand Prix track

shortDefinitions: prepared course or circuit for athletes, horses, motor vehicles, bicycles, or dogs to race on

definitions: the sport of running on a track.
shortDefinitions: sport of running on track

definitions: a mark or line of marks left by a person, animal, or vehicle in passing

examples.text: he followed the tracks made by the cars in the snow

shortDefinitions: mark or line of marks left by person

definitions: the course or route followed by someone or something (used especially in talking about their pursuit by others)

examples.text: I didn't want the Russians on my track

shortDefinitions: course or route followed by person or thing

definitions: a course of action; a way of proceeding

examples.text: defense budgeting and procurement do not move along different tracks from defense policy as a whole

shortDefinitions: course of action or line of thought

definitions: a continuous line of rails on a railroad

examples.text: commuters had to leave trains to walk along the tracks

shortDefinitions: continuous line of rails on railway

definitions: a metal or plastic strip or rail from which a curtain or spotlight may be hung or fitted.
shortDefinitions: metal or plastic strip or rail along which curtain or spotlight may be moved

definitions: a strip on the mast, boom, or deck of a yacht along which a slide attached to a sail can be moved, used to adjust the position of the sail.
shortDefinitions: strip on mast, boom, or floor of yacht along which slide attached to sail can be moved

definitions: a recording of one song or piece of music
etymologies: originally denoting a groove on a gramophone record

examples.text: the CD contains early Elvis Presley tracks

shortDefinitions: recording of one song or piece of music

definitions: a lengthwise strip of magnetic tape containing one sequence of signals.
shortDefinitions: lengthwise strip of magnetic tape containing one sequence of signals

definitions: the soundtrack of a film or video.
shortDefinitions: soundtrack of film or video

definitions: a continuous articulated metal band around the wheels of a heavy vehicle such as a tank or bulldozer, intended to facilitate movement over rough or soft ground.
shortDefinitions: continuous articulated metal band around wheels of heavy vehicle such as tank

definitions: a continuous line of copper or other conductive material on a printed circuit board, used to connect parts of a circuit

examples.text: extremely thin tracks are not able to withstand much heat when soldering

shortDefinitions: continuous line of copper or other conductive material on printed circuit board

definitions: the transverse distance between a vehicle's wheels.
shortDefinitions: transverse distance between vehicle's wheels

crossReferenceMarkers: British term stream (sense 4 of the noun)
definitions: a group in which schoolchildren of the same age and ability are taught.
shortDefinitions: group in which schoolchildren of same ability are taught

phrases.text: the wrong side of the tracks

definitions: follow the course or trail of (someone or something), typically in order to find them or note their location at various points

examples.text: secondary radars that track the aircraft in flight
he tracked Anna to her room

shortDefinitions: follow trail ora movements of person or thing

definitions: follow and note the course or progress of

examples.text: they are tracking the girth and evolution of stars

shortDefinitions: note progress or course of

definitions: follow a particular course

examples.text: the storm was tracking across the ground at 30 mph

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: follow particular course

definitions: (of a stylus) follow (a groove in a record)

examples.text: the pickup's stylus must faithfully track undulations

shortDefinitions: (of stylus) follow

definitions: (of a film or television camera) move in relation to the subject being filmed
etymologies: with reference to early filming when a camera was mobile by means of a track

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: (of film or television camera) move in relation to subject being filmed

definitions: (of wheels) run so that the back ones are exactly in the track of the front ones.
shortDefinitions: (of wheels) run so that back ones are exactly in track of front ones

definitions: (of a tunable circuit or component) vary in frequency in the same way as another circuit or component, so that the frequency difference between them remains constant.
shortDefinitions: (of tunable circuit or component) vary in frequency in same way as another circuit or component

definitions: assign (a student) to a course of study according to ability.
shortDefinitions: assign student to course of study according to ability

phrases.text: the wrong side of the tracks

etymologies: early 18th century: apparently from Dutch trekken ‘to draw, pull, or travel’. The change in the vowel was due to association with track

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

definitions: tow (a boat) along a waterway from the bank

examples.text: he was going to track the canoe up the ice-hung rapids

shortDefinitions: tow canoe along waterway from bank
